I accomplished what you are looking for as follows.  In my case it was to 
reuse some tests (without modification) that were present in a number of 
external files, so the filename was the parameter.

I created a test class that was a derived class of TestSuite.

Within that I declared a static inner class that derives from TestCase 
(though it could just as well be a separate non-inner public class)
The actual test is in the runTest method of the inner class.
The inner class has a constructor that takes arguments which are the 
variable parameters to the test, storing the values in 

In the constructor of the TestSuite I construct and add as tests instances 
of the inner TestCase for each set of parameters I want to run (by 
calling, for example, addTest(new InnerTestCase(...)); ).

Then I can run the test suite.  Each instance of the inner test case 
counts as a single test and is reported as so in the TestRunners - 
including in the test hierarchy display.  The TestSuite's run and 
countTestCases methods work without derivation, if I remember correctly. I 
think I did define a static suite() method for the TestSuite.  You can 
also add the outer Test Suite as an element of larger Test Suites.

Works great - the more I figured out how to properly use JUnit, the 
shorter my own code became.

I don't have the code here, but will be glad to send it to you directly if 
my approach is not clear from the discussion above.

- David

I have a standard test with needs to be run for different parameters.
I have created an XML file to define all the parameters and was
hoping to use JUnit to run the tests.

I cannot see how I can run the same method using different parameters.
e.g tests hcannot take paramters and methods are only called one.

I could have one test method that does the test for each parameter
set but JUnit I don't think allows you to continue after an assert.
Basically I want to treat each pass of the test  as a seperate
success/fail condition.

Any ideas ?
